newsitem.title: USA: IPO HIGHLIGHTS-IPOs surge, QAD a hit.
newsitem.headline: IPO HIGHLIGHTS-IPOs surge, QAD a hit.

text.p: Shares of QAD Inc, which makes enterprise resource planning software, surged in heavy trading after their initial public offering on Wednesday.
The stock leaped 45 percent to 21-3/4 and was one of the most heavily traded issues on the Nasdaq with more than 4.5 million shares exchanged.

Smith Barney was the lead underwriter of the $86 million IPO. Shares sold to IPO investors for $15 each, above initial price talk of $12 to $14. In response to the strong demand, underwriters moved the price range up to $15 to $16 a share.

QAD's principal software, MFG/PRO, is aimed to allow manufacturers to cut order fulfillment cycle times and inventories, measure company performance and boost operating efficiencies. It is specifically aimed at plants in five industries: food and beverage, consumer packaged goods, electronics and industrial, medical, and automotive.
Two Houston oil companies also made their IPO debuts:
-- Eagle Geophysical Inc shares opened with a gain of more than $2 each, at 19-3/4. Prudential led the offering of 5.88 million shares, with four million shares offered by Eagle.

Shares moved as high as 21 earlier but had settled at about 18-7/8 in afternoon trading. The shares sold to IPO investors for $17 each, the top of a range of $15 to $17, which was raised from an initial range of $14-$16.
The company sells high definition 3-D seismic data from wetland areas and congested offshore areas to drilling companies.

-- Carrizo Oil & Gas Inc also rose, though modestly, after its IPO. The oil and gas company exploration company "aggressively" seeks to control areas with proven oil and gas producing trends along the Gulf Coast, mostly near Texas and Louisiana, for 3-D seismic surveys.
Carrizo sold two million shares, which priced at $11, the low end of a price range of $11 to $13.
Shares were at 12-1/2, up from the IPO price of $11.
